title: The West Bank, a cauldron threatening to explode
summary: Anger is running high in the territory occupied by Israel where almost 200 Palestinians have been killed since October 7.

title: US lawmakers pass bill to avert government shutdown
summary: The US House of Representatives on Tuesday approved a stop-gap bill to keep the federal government operational through early 2024. The proposal does not include any military funding for Israel or Ukraine.

title: How dirty money and Russian riches flow through Cyprus, a gateway to the EU
summary: Tax advantages. Golden visas. Judicial leniency. The Cyprus Confidential investigation by Le Monde and its partners, based on leaks, sheds light on how the island's economic model was allowed abuses, despite warnings from anti-fraud watchdogs.

title: APEC Summit: Biden and Xi to meet in the US
summary: The upcoming second summit meeting between the American and Chinese presidents, within the framework of the annual Asia-Pacific meeting, seeks to reestablish a degree of stability in the deteriorating relationship between China and the United States.

title: German journalist was paid by Russian oligarch for pro-Putin books
summary: Confidential documents from the Cyprus Confidential investigation reveal that Hubert Seipel, known for his pro-Kremlin stance, received €600,000 from an offshore company linked to Russian billionaire Alexei Mordashov.

title: In Abidjan, Ivorians want to 'decolonize' chocolate
summary: Although Côte d'Ivoire supplies 45% of the world cocoa market, it has just 24 chocolate makers. Among them is Alain Kablan Porquet, who wants to usher in a new era of influence and power for cocoa-producing countries.

title: Paris will have residents vote on increasing parking fees for heavy SUVs
summary: The vote, to be held in February, will be the second city-wide referendum on urban matters, after residents in April voted to ban rental e-scooters from the capital.

title: French Sénat approves immigration bill after toughening it
summary: The Sénat amended the government's plan, shifting the bill's measures more to the right. The bill will be debated in the Assemblée Nationale in December.

title: Rothko, painter of the intimate and the intense
summary: In the abstract pieces he conceived after the war, which are on display at the Fondation Louis Vuitton until April 2, 2024, the American artist who rejected all labels sought to connect directly to the purity of human emotion.

title: Anti-Semitic acts in France rise to 1,500 since October 7
summary: France's Jewish population, the largest in Europe, has been targeted by a wave of anti-Semitism, despite the large turnout at a march against this discrimination on Sunday, October 12.

title: Russian convicted over journalist's murder pardoned for fighting in Ukraine
summary: Sergei Khadzhikurbanov was convicted of killing journalist Anna Politkovskaya in 2006. The Kremlin has acknowledged the use of prisoner recruits to fight in Ukraine and said convicts who 'atone for their crime on the battlefield with blood' could be pardoned.

title: Paris 2024: Tahiti residents question Olympics' impact on surfing spot
summary: The choice of Teahupo'o as the venue for the surfing event delighted fans. But many Tahitians are opposed to the construction of new infrastructure on this site for the Games, because of the irreparable damage to the coral reef ecosystem.

title: Judge recommends eight-month suspended term for French rugby player Chalureau over racist attack
summary: Bastien Chalureau, a second-row lock who was part of France's Rugby World Cup squad earlier this year, was appealing a sentence for 'acts of violence that were 'committed because of the race or ethnicity of the victim.'

title: Mali junta says it has 'seized' rebel stronghold of Kidal
summary: Mali's army said it had entered the northern town of Kidal, which has often been a stronghold of Tuareg-dominated rebel groups.

title: 250 flood-hit northern France towns in state of disaster
summary: President Emmanuel Macron said a state of natural disaster would be declared after heavy rains caused floods in the north of France. A €50 million fund will be made available to them.

title: Karim Khan, ICC prosecutor: 'Amidst conflict, amidst rage, there remains a baseline of humanity over which no individual may trespass'
summary: All parties to the conflict in Gaza and the West Bank must comply with international humanitarian law, which the International Criminal Court is committed to upholding, explains the Court's prosecutor, Karim Khan.

title: Sixty European banks suspected of influencing tensions in South Sudan
summary: The NGO Global Witness accused Deutsche Bank, Alliance, ING, and five major French financial establishments of financing two Chinese and Malaysian oil groups implicated in violence affecting the African country in the grip of civil war since 2013.

title: Tour de France 2025 edition will start from Lille
summary: The cycling race's 'Grand Départ' will be given from the northern French city, after three consecutive starts outside the country.

title: Israel says it has launched an operation in Gaza's largest hospital
summary: Israel says its forces have entered Gaza's Shifa hospital complex to target a suspected Hamas command center located beneath thousands of civilians seeking medical care and shelter.

title: 'The Killer,' on Netflix: A lone killer with a meticulous routine
summary: Much like its protagonist, a professional hitman who must eliminate his employers to save his own skin, David Fincher's film is straightforward and impactful in its storytelling.

title: US to resume food aid to Ethiopia following monitoring agreement
summary: In June, the US Agency for International Development stopped food aid to Ethiopia due to a suspected diversion of supplies, blamed on federal and regional authorities, with soldiers profiting from reselling donated food.

title: 'The Indian New Year is also a time for economic hope'
summary: The good economic health of the world's fifth-largest economy stands in stark contrast with the latest Chinese figures, which show a significant decline in consumption and exports.

title: US, China to launch joint climate action initiative
summary: In a joint statement, both governments on Wednesday announced the creation of a working group to tackle climate issues amid strained relations, ahead of Xi Jinping and Joe Biden's pivotal APEC summit encounter.

title: Secret payments cast doubt on Abramovich era at Chelsea
summary: Confidential documents reveal that the oligarch personally paid tens of millions of euros to leading figures in the world of football, at the risk of breaching UEFA regulations.

title: San Francisco dreams of being a 'beacon of peace' for relations between China and the US
summary: On the occasion of the annual Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, marked by a meeting between Joe Biden and Xi Jinping on November 15, San Francisco hopes to be the scene of a phase of geopolitical de-escalation.

title: Taiwan's opposition parties ally for 2024 presidential election
summary: The Kuomintang and Taiwan People's Party struck 'a cooperation agreement' after long discussions, though they have not yet decided which candidate will lead their ticket.

title: Australian spy agency warns state-backed hackers may target its submarines
summary: After several hacks in the last year, the Australian Signals Directorate report singled out Russia and China as among the country's greatest cyber threats and the AUKUS partnership's 'focus on nuclear submarines' as a likely target.

title: From diplomacy to domestic politics, Macron's fumbling confuses his allies
summary: The president's numerous statements about the war in Israel and Gaza have muddied his message. At home, he has struggled to find the right approach to the French public, disconcerting even his own supporters.

title: France issues arrest warrant for Syria's Bashar al-Assad
summary: The Syrian president is accused of complicity in crimes against humanity over the 2013 chemical attacks against his country's population.

title: UK court rules against plan to deport migrants to Rwanda
summary: The UK's Supreme Court has ruled against the UK government's plan to send asylum seekers to Rwanda, calling it unlawful. The Rwandan government has said it 'takes issue' with the ruling.

title: Flooding in northern France: Satellite images show scale of disaster
summary: Cloudy conditions over the northern Pas-de-Calais department of France have limited the number of satellite images that can be captured, but satellite image processing enables us to visualize the extent of the flooding.

title: 'Cantona Sings Eric,' a new, well-executed artistic project from the former footballer
summary: The former Manchester United striker is on tour, showing off a repertoire which he mostly wrote and composed himself. He played at the Théâtre de l'Atelier in Montmartre on Tuesday, November 14, in the first of three dates at the Parisian venue.

title: "Narco Business," an unprecedented video immersion into the heart of the drug cartels
summary: For two years, Bertrand Monnet, a French business school professor and specialist in the economics of crime, filmed every stage of the notorious Sinaloa cartel's business model in Mexico exclusively for Le Monde. In this first installment, we take an unprecedented dive into the laboratories behind M30, the fentanyl pill that is causing havoc in the United States.

title: Screening of footage of Hamas massacre divides French MPs
summary: On Tuesday, members of the Assemblée Nationale watched a film assembled by Israeli authorities. Some called it 'necessary,' while others criticized a process that might 'subject reason to emotion.'

title: Death of Nahel M.: French police officer who shot teen dead released under supervision
summary: The officer who fatally shot Nahel M. during a traffic stop in a suburb of Paris, in an incident that unleashed riots across France, has been charged with murder.

title: Tel Aviv's empty banquet, a symbol of the agonizing wait for families of Hamas's hostages
summary: A long table surrounded by empty chairs, set up in the heart of the city, symbolizes the absence of the 240 Israelis held prisoner by the Palestinian Islamist movement in Gaza.

title: Biden's pro-Israeli stance contested from within the US federal government
summary: Internal memos, notably from State Department diplomats, asked the American president to call for a ceasefire in Gaza and to be more critical of Israel.

title: Antoine Dupont to play at Paris Olympics 2024
summary: French rugby star Antoine Dupont will miss the Six Nations in order to prepare to play seven-a-side rugby at the Olympic Games in Paris next year.

title: Greta Thunberg pleads not guilty to public order offence after arrest in London
summary: The climate activist was arrested at a protest in London against the energy sector in October. She denied the offence in court on Wednesday.

title: Jewish gravestones vandalized in German WWI cemetery in northern France
summary: Ten Jewish graves were damaged in a German military cemetery in the Oise region. Police have launched an investigation.

title: Macron sends defense minister on Middle East tour
summary: Defense Minister Sébastien Lecornu's unexpected trip, which began in Egypt and is due to end in Israel on Friday, is intended to clarify France's position following the president's controversial remarks.
